page.title: 11Local history of Stratton
page.content: Stone and field monuments are to be seen. Traces of Iron Age fields and settlement enclosures are at Grimstone Down. A dry summer reveals the route of the Roman road crossing the valley, thus the name of Stratton.The Roman aqueduct, most visible at the bend above Bradford Peverell church, was a leat carrying millions of gallons a day to Dorchester. The watermeadows were constructed in the late 18th century to obtain early grass by daily flooding of the valley floor. The Doles, still bounded by hedges, are a remnant of the strip farming system of the middle ages.Jackman's Cross is reputedly the site of a hanging for sheep stealing. An 18th century sheep dip is at the bottom of Mill Lane, which leads to the mill. The wheel is still present, but not operating.
